property.name: Name
property.comment: Name of the project ("Scarab" for the standard distribution).

property.name: version
property.comment: Project version.

property.name: project
property.comment: Name of the project, used for???.

property.name: year
property.comment: Year, possibly used for copyright message.

property.name: scarab.database.name
property.comment: I don't know whether Torque needs building with the database name or not. If not, this can just be a runtime property.

property.name: scarab.database.port
property.comment: The port that the database is running on.

property.name: scarab.database.jdbc.driver
property.comment: The JDBC driver to use for the database connection. We supply standard ones for several databases, but users should have the option to supply their own.

property.name: scarab.database.url
property.comment: This property is specific to a database driver and is built up from other user-specified properties. I guess this goes hand-in-hand with 'scarab.database.jdbc.driver'.

property.name: scarab.database.admin.url
property.comment: JDBC URL to use when creating and seeding the database.

property.name: scarab.database.admin.username
property.comment: Database user to use when creating and seeding the database.

property.name: scarab.database.admin.password
property.comment: Password to use when creating and seeding the database.

property.name: scarab.test.database.name
property.comment: I think this is the name of the test database used for running unit tests against, so it should be a build property. Not sure though.

property.name: scarab.test.database.url
property.comment: JDBC URL used to connect to the test database.

property.name: scarab.database.validationQuery
property.comment: Not sure this property should be available at all. I would hard-code it per database type.

property.name: scarab.jdbc.driver.jar
property.comment: I guess this works in a similar fashion to 'scarab.database.jdbc.driver'. If one is set by the user, so should the other. Normally these should be provided as defaults on a per database type basis.

property.name: scarab.database.loadorder
property.comment: Drop this? Don't know whether it's still useful.

property.name: scarab.context
property.comment: What shall we do with this? Normally the context comes from the name of the deployed WAR file, unless a different context name is configured in server.xml. Maybe just allow the user to configure the context name via server.xml directly?

property.name: scarab.http.domain
property.comment: This also appears in the database, and I'm really not sure what to do about it. It causes a lot of problems with the generated e-mail links.

property.name: scarab.http.port
property.comment: See 'scarab.http.domain'.

property.name: scarab.http.scheme
property.comment: Drop this? I guess that this is used for generating e-mail links.

property.name: scarab.http.scriptname
property.comment: Drop this? Most people seem to have problems when this is set to something other than /scarab/issues anyway.

property.name: scarab.html.redirect
property.comment: I think this is configured in server.xml as a filter. Maybe the user should just change it there directly.

property.name: scarab.user.username
property.comment: Username of the initial (only?) Scarab administrator. Maybe this, along with the other adminstrator user properties, should be build properties which modify the seed data. Otherwise use hard-coded values.

property.name: scarab.user.password
property.comment: Password for initial Scarab administrator.

property.name: scarab.lucene.index.path
property.comment: Where the Lucene index files are stored on disk.

property.name: scarab.attachments.path
property.comment: Where issue attachments are stored on disk.

property.name: scarab.intake.serialize.file
property.comment: Scratch/hard-code this one? Seems too obscure to have lying around.

property.name: scarab.file.upload.path
property.comment: Temporary location on disk for uploaded files.

property.name: scarab.system.mail.host
property.comment: Mail server that Scarab should use to send e-mails.

property.name: scarab.email.default.fromName
property.comment: E-mail name that e-mails from Scarab have in their 'from' address.

property.name: scarab.email.default.fromAddress
property.comment: The 'from' address for e-mails that are sent by Scarab. I think this generally needs to be a valid e-mail address, or at least a valid domain. I vaguely remember someone having problems because they were using the default from address which had an invalid domain. Something didn't like it.
